awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Award: Examination of Long Term Environmental Impact of Grazing
awd_abstract_narration:
Research topics on environmental change and degradation span multiple scholarly disciplines and speak to varying concerns across different populations and audiences. Archaeological research plays an important role in conversations on environmental change as it can investigate human-environmental interactions across greater time scales and provide important insight on the ways society, politics, and economy both shape and are shaped by the environment.  Looking at prehistoric and early historic time periods, this project uses an archaeological approach to investigate how histories of animal husbandry, agricultural production, and political economy intersected to produce complex environmental histories. Investigating specific articulations between human activities and changes in the environmental record at deeper time scales will ultimately provide a stronger empirical context to guide public and scholarly debate as well as inform environmental conservation policies.
 
 Under the direction of Dr. Kathleen Morrison, Co-PI Kelly Wilcox Black will conduct faunal and dental microwear analysis on animal remains from an archaeological site located in South India (Kadebakele, Karnataka India). The researcher will combine faunal and dental microwear datasets with vegetation and remote sensing data in order to investigate whether and under what circumstances, intensified forms of land and animal use corresponded with deforestation, overgrazing, and soil erosion. This case study will specifically examine questions related to shifts in resource production strategies and their environmental impacts over the course of the Neolithic, Iron Age, and Early Historic periods in South India. This particular temporal context is important because it captures a diverse set of social and economic practices, including the beginnings of animal domestication in the region, as well as the subsequent emergence of towns and urban economies. An empirically informed study concerning the relationship between different modes of political economy, resource production, and changes in vegetation, soils, and landforms will be specifically relevant to contemporary environment conservation programs in South Asia. Such programs depict processes such has pastoralism and animal grazing as inherently environmentally destructive despite the fact that the long-term impacts of grazing are poorly understood. The results from this research will provide a much-needed long-term perspective on the impacts of intensified agricultural production and livestock grazing and will critically evaluate how the empirical evidence can be read against the assumptions and ideologies that are built into existing conservation programs.  Although this example is specific to the environmental concerns and policies existing in South Asia, the analytical framework provided can be replicated in other regions and provide insight into present day global environmental concerns. Importantly, this research will use archaeological evidence not only to help illustrate the complexity underlying human-environmental interactions over time, but to also reconstruct how populations in the past perceived episodes of environmental stress and how they responded to them, offering new and diverse perspectives into how to cope with and potentially remedy particular forms of environmental degradation.

por.por_cntn:
Under this project, Co-PI Kelly Wilcox Black combined multiple lines of archaeological evidence in order to investigate changes in animal husbandry organization and the environmental impacts of livestock grazing throughout the South Indian Neolithic (3000 BCE-1200BCE), Iron Age (1200BCE-300BCE), and Early Historic (300BCE-500CE) periods.  Co-PI first conducted faunal analysis (the analysis of animal bones from archaeological sites) using animal bones recovered from the site Kadebakele. Next, Co-PI conducted dental microwear analysis (the analysis of microscopic features on tooth enamel surfaces in order to reconstruct animal diet). 

Data from faunal analysis show subsistence practices throughout the Neolithic, Iron Age, and Early Historic periods contained a lot of similarities.  Kadebakele inhabitants engaged in hunting and herding practices.  They hunted a variety of locally available non-mammalian wild taxa (i.e. fish, birds, turtles) and reared domesticates like cattle and sheep and goats for secondary products (wool, dairy, and labor). 

By the middle of the Iron Age, Kadebakele inhabitants began deliberate efforts to maximize dairy production in sheep and goats. Interestingly, however, cattle were not reared in the same way.  Although cattle likely contributed to the dairy economy as well, it does not appear cattle were slaughtered for the purposes of maximizing resource production.  The age data show cattle often lived, and were cared for, well into advanced age and beyond their prime age for resource yields.  Cattle thus appear to have had value that went beyond economic or subsistence use. Their importance is further attested to by their presence in specially prepared features found in megaliths (ritual structures) during the Iron Age at Kadebakele.

Dental microwear results are preliminary, but show that over half of the teeth recovered from the Iron Age are heavily striated, an indication that animals fed on overgrazed pastures. Thus intensified dairy production observed during the Iron Age, along with the rearing of cattle well into advanced age may have led to high stocking levels (many grazing animals on the landscape) and resulted in at least some instances of overgrazing. 

In contrast to the Iron Age, none of the teeth recovered from the Early Historic period were heavily striated.  Faunal data also show that domesticates decreased in proportion compared to wild taxa. The small faunal sample from the Early Historic period makes it difficult to draw definitive conclusions, however it may be the case that the decrease in domesticates on site reflects the adoption of a mobile pastoral strategy. Evidence that animals were grazed further away from the site during this period is supported by survey research that has identified various pastoral camps throughout the region. A more mobile grazing system also would have allowed a pastoral production system to be maintained as more land was allocated for agricultural and rice production during the Early Historic period.

The shift between the Iron Age and the Early Historic period suggests that Kadebakele inhabitants may have recognized problems related to overgrazing and sought to alleviate grazing pressure by expanding pasture ranges, reducing herd sizes, or both. Failing to mitigate problems related to overgrazing ultimately would have undermined the health of animals that served as important dietary, economic, and ritual resources. 

To summarize, the outcomes of this research project make significant contributions to understandings of animal husbandry throughout prehistoric and Early Historic South India and provide a model case study for reconstructing the interplay of animal husbandry, agricultural production, and the environmental impacts of livestock grazing from a long-term perspective. This research argues that intensified forms of resource production articulated with changes in pasture quality and argues that perceptions of changes in the environment, along with the value and importance placed on animal health, helped shape future land use and subsistence organization choices.

The results of this research address NSF’s intellectual merit requirement by advancing knowledge across multiple disciplines, including anthropology, archaeology, political ecology, environmental history, and South Asian studies.  Importantly, it provides key information on human-environmental interactions and human-animal relationships and focuses on the less well-studied pre-colonial period in South Asia.

The results of this research address NSF’s broader impacts requirement by contributing data on the history of grazing in South Asia. Environmental conservation policies are often informed by degradation narratives that lack both data and nuance in their portrayal of environmental problems and how best to resolve them. This research impacts society by providing a way of engaging in environmental conservation discourse that contains specific data on the history of livestock grazing in South Asia and by capturing how societies in the past perceived and responded to environmental stress. Knowledge of how past societies navigated problem-solving with respect to environmental stress is useful, in particular where it presents a new and diverse perspective to be considered in ongoing debates over how to approach environmental concerns.
